Dear Ms. Sander:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
November 19, 2024. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written
corrective action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date
of this letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Samantha Way, area manager at (517) 243- 9743.
Sincerely,
Pinkey Brown, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation
• (5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the
evaluation, an agency shall complete a written
report that includes all the following information:
• (c) Dates and places of contacts, names of
persons interviewed, and names of the
interviewers. If children are interviewed,
their last names may not be included in the
report.
One of two special evaluations reviewed included the foster child’s first and last
names in the special evaluation report.
CPA Rule 400.12605 Adoptive family evaluation
• (1) An agency social service worker shall
complete a written adoptive evaluation within 90
days of the family signing an adoption application
and prior to approving a family for adoption
Three of six case files were reviewed, three adoptive evaluation reports were written
past the 90 days required of the family signing the application.

VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with this individual CAP is as follows: The
agency submitted a corrective action plan (CAP) during this licensing period in
response to the 2023 renewal inspection completed on 7/10/2023 and the CAP
was approved on 8/4/2023. The agency was cited for 6 violations. During this
reporting period, there were no repeat violations.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator Assessment was reviewed. The Chief Administrator (CA)
reported that the retention of front-line staff continues to be a challenge for the
agency. She reported the agency experienced a significant period of stability with
zero turnover in the last quarter. The CA reported this is attributed to continuous
efforts to recruit and retain staff with realistic expectations for the position and who
possess significant skills and credentials, as well as training and support of
supervisors. She said a commitment to reduce caseload size, proactive planning
for staff departures, frequent check-ins and support of new staff and constant
assessment and improvements in staff salaries and benefits. CA reported still,
staff are challenged by an observed increase in the intensity and acuity of the
needs of the children and parents served, who present with significant barriers to
reunification and ability to benefit from services. Systemic gaps in adequate
mental health services for both children and adults and lack of affordable and
available housing also present barriers in the agency work. The CA reported
another barrier is the delays in the processing of fingerprints by DCWL, consent
from MCI (especially in competing party cases), as well as court delays throughout
this year continue to present significant barriers to timely permanency for children.
3

Lack of accountability and poor communication at times are factors which
perpetuate and cause tension in collaborative relationships with DHHS. CA
summarized this by stating the personal and professional stressors experienced
over the past four years undoubtedly continue to impact staff, but have been
mitigated significantly by strong, extremely hardworking leadership, focus on staff
mental and physical health and a clear message to staff that HATW's commitment
to safety, compliance and service to families will not change, despite continued
external challenges.
Financial Overview
The CA submitted the agency independent financial audit dated December 31,
2023, and 2022. The agency annual budget was also submitted. Based on
review, there are no financial concerns.
Staff Interviews
Interviews were conducted with three staff members onsite on 8/24/2024. Staff
reported feeling supported by the agency. Staff reported that supervisors and
coworkers were available and will assist when needed. The staff reported they
would not change anything currently about the agency and enjoy working in the
environment the agency administration, has created. The staff interviewed did not
report any concerns.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency maintains sufficient office space, equipment and supplies to ensure
delivery of foster care, licensing and adoption services. All files were stored
securely and there is a cross shredder for CHRI.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no safety concerns.
4

VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
